page.title: 14LITTLE BADDOW CANAL-1
page.content: The Chelmer and Blackwater canal is a stretch of the River Chelmer which was made navigable in 1797.The canal runs for 22km from the Heybridge Basin to the Springfield Basin; from Maldon to Chelmsford. The canal includes 12 locks, 11 on the river and 1 sea lock. It has a total fall of 76 feet and 11 inches. Originally the canal was used for the transportation of coal and bulky raw materials. Between 1797 and 1845 this was a profitable venture and continued to be so between 1846 and 1865. From 1866 to 1914 the Company declined as a Navigation as railways could viably compete with the canal and this decline continued further from 1915 and 1973 when it ceased to operate as a system of transport and trade.
